Award.AwardTitle: New Molecular Systems Based on Indenofluorenes and Expanded Quinoidal Analogues: Experimental, Theoretical, and Materials Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry Division supports the research of Professor Michael Haley in the Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry at the University of Oregon. Prof. Haley and his students are preparing molecules based on or inspired by the indenofluorene skeleton to answer fundamental scientific questions as well as to explore their materials properties. A key goal is to develop simple synthetic methods for the assembly of these strongly electron-accepting molecules. Once in hand, the Haley group examines the optical and electronic properties of all new molecular scaffolds with an emphasis towards utilization of these materials in optoelectronic devices such as organic field effect transistors (OFETs) and organic photovoltaics (OPVs). The broader impacts of this program include industrial internships for graduate students at local and regional companies, the exchange of graduate students with those of foreign collaborators, the hosting of extended stays of visiting scientists including professors from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs), and continued substantial involvement of undergraduates in chemical research via programs which promote participation of underrepresented groups.


Research on non-benzenoid molecules has experienced a renaissance over the last decade as chemists have recognized their potential as organic semiconductors characterized by low Highest Occupied Molecular Orbitals (HOMO) and Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbitals (LUMO) energy levels and small energy gaps. This projects sets out to: (1) explore the fundamental properties and reactivity of the fully conjugated indenofluorene (IF) core leading to asymmetrically derivatized structures, (2) prepare a library of derivatized IFs and IF-diones for detailed structure-properties relationship studies, (3) extend our synthetic routes for the preparation and study of unknown, fully conjugated topologies such as indeno[1,2-a]fluorenes and indacenodiacenes, and (4) prepare expanded quinoidal IF analogues based diindeno-fused acenes and explore their open shell/biradical character. The molecules developed in these studies present opportunities for practical applications, particularly in the area of nanotechnology and low-cost electronics. Moreover, this project serves as an excellent training ground for graduate and undergraduate researchers in fundamental and applied chemical synthesis. The studies provides the researchers with broad experience in organic synthesis, computational chemistry, x-ray crystallography, and the interplay between electronic structure and molecular architecture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 30+ years, research on polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) has undergone a remarkable renaissance in the chemical literature as compound preparation and classification have been made easier with the advent of modern laboratory synthetic methods and modern characterization techniques. One key motivation to this resurgence lies within the unique optoelectronic properties that PAHs possess because of their inherently high levels of pi-electron conjugation and delocalization. These attributes make PAHs useful as organic semiconducting molecules for a variety of materials applications such as organic photovoltaics (OPVs), organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), and organic field-effect transistors (OFETs). While a majority of studies have focused on molecules called acenes and related derivatives, these molecules are susceptible to oxidative and photolytic degradation. Given that problem, there is a pressing need for alternative, more stable, acene-like structures.

Nontraditional structures that incorporate five-membered cyclopentane rings (CP-PAHs) such as the fullerenes and related ?bucky bowls? have undergone rapid growth as well. This NSF grant focused on the pentacyclic indenofluorene (IF) framework along with closely related structural derivatives, where two rings within the larger framework are five-membered rings. With NSF support, we have developed and/or adapted general methods for the construction of a wide variety of  fully conjugated, highly colored IF derivatives (see Figure) and have been exploring their materials properties. What makes the study of these unusual molecules so rewarding is that IFs, in addition to being challenging synthetic targets, provide fundamental answers about structure, bonding, and reactivity in expanded, conjugated structures, and have the potential to act as planar, rigid, electron accepting cores for the preparation of advanced materials with novel electronic properties.

Work on this NSF grant has led to several key findings regarding indenofluorenes: (1) by altering the fused aromatic rings in a systematic manner, we can rationally ?tune? energy levels and energy gaps; (2) expanding the benzene core to either naphthalene or anthracene and then doing the same structural tuning of the outer rings permits us to rationally alter diradical properties; (3) fusing aromatic heterocycles to the aforementioned cores provides molecules that are even more antiaromatic/more diradical than the molecules that serve as our benchmarks; and (4) rather than using computations to rationalize experimental results, we are now able to predict what molecular structures to synthesize in the lab. All of these findings permit researchers to tune molecule properties to those desired or deemed useful for organic electronic applications.

The broader impacts of this program have included industrial internships of graduate students at local and regional companies, the exchange of graduate students with those of several foreign collaborators, the hosting of extended stays of visiting scientists including professors from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs), and continued substantial involvement of undergraduates in chemical research via programs that promote participation of underrepresented groups. The molecules developed in these studies present opportunities for practical applications, particularly in the area of nanotechnology and low-cost electronics. Moreover, this project has served as an excellent training ground for graduate and undergraduate researchers in fundamental and applied chemical synthesis. These studies have provided the researchers with broad experience in organic synthesis, computational chemistry,  and x-ray crystallography, thus allowing researchers to better understand the interplay between electronic structure and molecular architecture.
